This is one of the most touching stories I have experienced. Not just in a game, in general. 


While the gameplay is solid, combat feels good and exploration can be tedious, the narrative, the performances and the music together with visuals tell a beautiful tale of redemption, change, growth, choice... 

We all can be better and we must be better. For the sake of our children.


I highly recommend this game to anyone who cares about narratives in videogames. Be mindful that it can make you cry.

I wanted to love God of War Ragnar√∂k the same way I loved the first one. The 2018 game was the first video game that truly pulled me in, and I could not get enough of it. The story, the pacing, the connection between Kratos and Atreus. Everything felt powerful. Everything felt meaningful. I was excited for the sequel thinking it would give me that same feeling again.

Instead, I found myself frustrated almost the entire time.

The biggest problem for me is being forced to play as Atreus. In the first game he felt like a helper. He supported you, he added to the story, and his moments made sense. In Ragnar√∂k it feels like the entire game shifts to being about him. And not in a subtle or natural way. The writing pushes him into the spotlight so hard that Kratos feels pushed into the background.

Atreus comes across as whiny, impulsive, and constantly making choices that make everything worse. It is exhausting to play through his sections. Every time I was switched to him, I felt myself wanting to rush through it just to get back to Kratos. I lost count of how many times I caught myself sighing and thinking here we go again. The pacing falls apart because of it. The story keeps dragging you away from the part you actually want to play.

The worst part is that the game itself looks amazing. The world is gorgeous. The combat is still strong. The environments are detailed. It has everything it needs to be great, but the story choice to center so much of the experience on Atreus took the joy out of it for me.

With the first God of War, I could not put the controller down. I stayed up late. I cried. I cared. With Ragnar√∂k, I kept putting the controller down and trying to talk myself into picking it back up. I still have not finished it because the motivation is just not there. Every time I think about continuing, I remember how it felt the last time I was forced into another Atreus section and I stop.

I know some people enjoyed the direction they took, but for me it was disappointing. If someone asked me which one to play, I would tell them without hesitation to play the first God of War. The emotional weight and the pacing of the first game are on a completely different level.

Ragnar√∂k had all the potential in the world, but it never connected with me the way the first one did. I wish it had.

Gameplay is very good as expected. It is fun and opens a lot of options for player to find their play style. Perfect in every sense.

Only part I did not enjoy was when Atreus and Angrboda met. Going with her felt like a big chore to get off the list. Athreus here acted like a spoiled teenager which made it harder to connect with him as a character. Another less enjoyable part was Vanaheim. Story here was going off the tracks.

Level design of Jotunheim and afterwards Vanaheim where packed with all sorts off colours and details. This made it harder to focus on your view. Felt like it was too saturated and contrasted. However Midgard, Muspleheim and Svartalfeheim were the way to go!

There were some silly parts like Kratos making the room dark and extinguishing 1 out 10 candles. Nothing critically bad.

Due to game crashing on my side, Valhalla DLC is unplayable. As each crash reset the run back to beginning I am unable to complete the runs.

OVERALL, if you liked the first game (AND YOU SHOULD!) you will like this one. This is is a must for everyone!

One of the worst games in recent memory was God of War 2018. A long, drawn out, soulless adventure that took everything you loved about God of War originally and threw it out the window to become a Last of Us styled Sony Movie cutscene bullshit experience. No fun boss fights, a terrible combat system, shoehorned RPG elements, a focus on story over actual gameplay, and worst of all, some truly annoying characters. (Atreus.) God of War 2018 was a trainwreck, a game that fundamentally ruined my favorite franchise of all time, and now, years later, after sitting through that garbage for the platinum, Ragnarok is upon us. Would you believe me if i said this is actually an improvement over 2018 in one singular aspect, and a completely separate trainwreck in almost every other regard? Isn't that amazing? Even the morons that enjoyed 2018 don't like this game. Sony's dedication to making every game play and feel exactly the same is admirable.
Anyway, I will give credit where it is due. This games combat is a marked improvement over 2018, so much so that looking at gameplay of 2018 just reiterates to me how terrible that game was. Kratos having 3 weapons adds a lot, especially having the blades right at the start. I enjoy the spear gameplay, and the overall flow of combat is much better, more enemies, less waiting around than 2018, and amazingly, actual enemy variety, which was one of the worst parts about 2018. So basically, the game is fun when you are fighting something, and every other time is a boring, vapid, overblown and overdramatic mess. Not a good mix.
The only other positive I can give is this. The character designs for the Norse gods encountered here are cool, especially Thor. Odin looks appropriately shifty and evil, and I especially like the attention to actual Norse mythos with designs such as Hiemdall. I enjoy the mythology, and same as 2018, Mimir and his stories are a highlight.
Onto the bad. This game is boring as hell. It is too long, too overdramatic, and more than anything it is boring beyond belief. The story is pitiful, actually worse and less engaging than 2018, (I can't believe they managed that), and the characters are annoying and contrived, and worst of all is the tone. This feels like a marvel movie, and that is not a good thing. These two norse games have had two good characters, Kratos and Mimir, and just when you're trudging through the game at a snail's pace, just wanting to get to the action, it actually makes you play as Atreus. My jaw dropped, really. Any Atreus section is boring, and the combat sucks so much ass it makes you wanna turn the game to easy mode and just skip all the tedium. Atreus is not as annoying as he was in 2018, but at the same time he is still so annoying that nothing has really changed. The segment of Ironwood alone almost made me give up on this bullshit but I had to see it through. The story beats are predictable, contrived, and the ending is so, so unsatisfying, even compared to 2018. The twist was admirable as an attempt, but ultimately feels flat, especially in the postgame where you actually meet the real Tyr. What an absolute waste of what could have been an interesting dynamic, Tyr and Kratos, two very different gods of war. At least it had a few unique boss fights, unlike 2018, so I will give it that credit.
The one saving grace of this game is actually the stupid roguelike mode if you can believe that. While 2018 had a god awful attempt at something like this, Valhalla is, to put it simply, entertaining. No dumb characters to listen to whine, no stupid exploration at a snail's pace, just combat. That's all this game is good for. The callbacks to Greece, old weapons, old enemies, a familiar face, and the overall story of Valhalla was the only time during this game I actually felt like I gave a shit about anything. Kratos is my favorite character in anything ever, and when he isn't surrounded by marvel characters and stupid side characters like that dumbass squirrel, he can shine. But as soon as you start getting into the groove of it, It's over. I took my trophies and dipped, because it offers little after the fact.
Don't let the 90 hours of gametime fool you, this game sucks ass upon ass. I would rather play it than 2018, simply for the combat's sake, but that is a vapid statement, as I would rather die than ever touch either of these games again. I play and platinum them so that I can explain to you how garbage they are, and when the next godawful God of war sequel comes out, where they will inevitably force you to play as Atreus again, I will be here, in the reviews, to let you know that it's just as garbage as the last two. This franchise use to mean something to me, and though Valhalla offered glimpses back into the fun and exciting era of Greece, where everything was bombastic, exciting, and more than anything entertaining, the success of these two Norse games will no doubt keep us from ever having the franchise return to it's roots. It is a shame, and that's exactly how I would describe this game. While 2018 was abysmal, a slap in the face even, Ragnarok is somehow worse. You see the glimpses of fun in the heat of combat, and feel shame that this franchise has been reduced to a Last of Us ripoff. If you think this is a good game, I hope for your sake that you are on medication or currently seeking asylum.

I enjoy the spear gameplay, and the overall flow of combat is much better, more enemies, less waiting around than 2018, and amazingly, actual enemy variety, which was one of the worst parts about 2018. So basically, the game is fun when you are fighting something, and every other time is a boring, vapid, overblown and overdramatic mess. Not a good mix.
The only other positive I can give is this. The character designs for the Norse gods encountered here are cool, especially Thor. Odin looks appropriately shifty and evil, and I especially like the attention to actual Norse mythos with designs such as Hiemdall. I enjoy the mythology, and same as 2018, Mimir and his stories are a highlight.
Onto the bad. This game is boring as hell. It is too long, too overdramatic, and more than anything it is boring beyond belief. The story is pitiful, actually worse and less engaging than 2018, (I can't believe they managed that), and the characters are annoying and contrived, and worst of all is the tone. This feels like a marvel movie, and that is not a good thing. These two norse games have had two good characters, Kratos and Mimir, and just when you're trudging through the game at a snail's pace, just wanting to get to the action, it actually makes you play as Atreus. My jaw dropped, really. Any Atreus section is boring, and the combat sucks so much ass it makes you wanna turn the game to easy mode and just skip all the tedium. Atreus is not as annoying as he was in 2018, but at the same time he is still so annoying that nothing has really changed. The segment of Ironwood alone almost made me give up on this bullshit but I had to see it through. The story beats are predictable, contrived, and the ending is so, so unsatisfying, even compared to 2018. The twist was admirable as an attempt, but ultimately feels flat, especially in the postgame where you actually meet the real Tyr. What an absolute waste of what could have been an interesting dynamic, Tyr and Kratos, two very different gods of war. At least it had a few unique boss fights, unlike 2018, so I will give it that credit.
The one saving grace of this game is actually the stupid roguelike mode if you can believe that. While 2018 had a god awful attempt at something like this, Valhalla is, to put it simply, entertaining. No dumb characters to listen to whine, no stupid exploration at a snail's pace, just combat. That's all this game is good for. The callbacks to Greece, old weapons, old enemies, a familiar face, and the overall story of Valhalla was the only time during this game I actually felt like I gave a shit about anything. Kratos is my favorite character in anything ever, and when he isn't surrounded by marvel characters and stupid side characters like that dumbass squirrel, he can shine. But as soon as you start getting into the groove of it, It's over. I took my trophies and dipped, because it offers little after the fact.
Don't let the 90 hours of gametime fool you, this game sucks ass upon ass. I would rather play it than 2018, simply for the combat's sake, but that is a vapid statement, as I would rather die than ever touch either of these games again. I play and platinum them so that I can explain to you how garbage they are, and when the next godawful God of war sequel comes out, where they will inevitably force you to play as Atreus again, I will be here, in the reviews, to let you know that it's just as garbage as the last two. This franchise use to mean something to me, and though Valhalla offered glimpses back into the fun and exciting era of Greece, where everything was bombastic, exciting, and more than anything entertaining, the success of these two Norse games will no doubt keep us from ever having the franchise return to it's roots. It is a shame, and that's exactly how I would describe this game. While 2018 was abysmal, a slap in the face even, Ragnarok is somehow worse. You see the glimpses of fun in the heat of combat, and feel shame that this franchise has been reduced to a Last of Us ripoff. If you think this is a good game, I hope for your sake that you are on medication or currently seeking asylum.

I think one of the laziest sequels to follow up from such an incredible original (GOW 2018). This is one of the purest examples of publishers adding time rather than value in order to make a game feel more substantial: More collectibles to fill time; More backtracking to collect said collectibles; Unskippable cutscenes; Small, non-threatening, unnecessary fights whenever you approach a chest (because they lock chests during combat and adding a fight before opening a chest adds time (BUT PROVIDES NO VALUE)); Lackluster overworld compared to last game (Tyr's temple vs. B&S's Treehouse); repetitive puzzles that only block your physical progression but don't provide any reward; walking simulators for hours that still provide no story progression and only filler fights (looking at you Atreus); lock-stepping inventory upgrades to story progression forcing investment of TIME; and adding forced side quests masquerading as main quests but that have nothing to do with the overarching story. This game steals your time in order to try to trick you into thinking its providing a substantial experience. It is not.

Slowest game I've played in a long time. I am 11 hours in and I am still confused with no motivation to continue, hoping that clarity is just around the corner (it never is). Arguments between characters are endless loops with no closure until one is proven right or wrong by a certain story event. Any story progression is dampened with either a character's reluctance or a vague "you'll understand this reveal at a later date." Then what's the point in revealing it? 

This game feels like they planned a trilogy, realized 3 years into developing Ragnarok that they didn't have enough story for a trilogy, didn't change their release timeline, kept everything they worked on, then dropped the finale in right where they left off working on this one, and then slapped a $60 sticker on it.

This is a far cry from the previous game despite its similar, shiny exterior. At least the combat folks did their job. But for a story-driven, immersive game, this should not have been acceptable. Santa Monica should not be proud to put their name on this game for their asking price.
